title-group.article-title: Effective property estimates for composites containing multiple nanoheterogeneities: Part I Nanospheres, nanoplatelets, and voids

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Aerospace Engineering, Mississippi State University, USA
2Dave C. Swalm School of Chemical Engineering, Mississippi State University, USA
3Department of Chemistry, Mississippi State University, USA

author-notes.corresp: Thomas E Lacy, Department of Aerospace Engineering, Mississippi State University, USA. Email: lacy@ae.msstate.edu

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Effective Continuum Micromechanics Analysis Code (EC-MAC) was developed to predict effective properties of composites containing multiple distinct nanoheterogeneities (fibers, spheres, platelets, voids, etc.) each with an arbitrary number of coating layers based upon either the modified Mori–Tanaka method or the self-consistent method. The influence of solid and hollow nanoreinforcement geometries and distinct elastic properties was addressed for solid silica nanosphere/epoxy, hollow glass nanosphere/polyester, and α-zirconium phosphate nanoplatelet/epoxy composites, along with the influence of spherical voids. The notion of “effective volume fraction” was introduced to denote the fraction of nanoreinforcements that contribute to overall composite properties through their good dispersion. The predicted nanocomposite effective elastic moduli obtained using the Effective Continuum Micromechanics Analysis Code matched well with experimental results from the literature.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Polymer matrix composites (PMCs) are widely used in structural applications due to their good elastic properties, tailorability, and multi-functionality.1–3 In recent years, PMCs reinforced with TiO2,4 polypropylene,5 and polyethylene nanospheres,6 nickel + aluminum nanoparticles,7 solid silica nanospheres,8 hollow glass spheres,9 graphite nanoplatelets,10–14 α-zirconium phosphate (α-ZrP) nanoplatelets,15 vapor grown carbon nanofibers (VGCNFs),16–18 and carbon nanotubes (CNTs)19–21 have been developed with the goal of obtaining significant material property enhancements resulting from these nanoreinforcements’ high surface-area-to-volume ratios. Recent studies have emphasized the development of analytic and numerical material models to facilitate nanomaterial design in order to minimize the required specimen preparation and testing.22,23

Effective composite properties depend on several factors including nanoreinforcement volume fraction, size, orientation, morphology, and dispersion. Composite materials manufacturing processes play a crucial role in determining those factors.24 Fabricating composites with well-dispersed and preferentially oriented nanoreinforcements remains a significant challenge. Adding small amounts of nanoreinforcements can increase liquid resin viscosities by over an order of magnitude.25,26 This may increase void content due to difficulties in degassing prior to curing, particularly at higher nanoreinforcement volume fractions. Moreover, poorly dispersed or agglomerated nanoreinforcements become a significant concern as the volume fraction of reinforcements or resin viscosity is increased. Only well dispersed nanoreinforcements may be “effective” in enhancing composite stiffness and strength properties. The remaining fraction of nanoreinforcements contained in agglomerates or otherwise poorly distributed may lead to a significant reduction in bulk composite properties, particularly strength.

In this work, the Effective Continuum Micromechanics Analysis Code (EC-MAC) was developed to estimate effective stiffness properties for composites containing multiple nanoheterogeneities (spheres, platelets, voids, etc.), based upon the Mori–Tanaka and self-consistent micromechanical models. The influence of nanoreinforcement geometries and distinct elastic properties is addressed. EC-MAC is capable of treating either hollow or solid reinforcements, each with an arbitrary number of surrounding interphase layers (coatings). In the second part of this study, Yu et al.27 investigate composites reinforced with hollow wavy carbon nanofibers, as well as composites containing reinforcements of disparate sizes (i.e., nanofibers combined with traditional E-glass fibers). The notion of the effective volume fraction of nanoreinforcements is more fully addressed in Yu et al.27

sec.title: Nanoreinforcement dimensions and properties
sec.p: Nanoreinforcements (nanospheres, nanoplatelets, nanofibers, etc.) can have distinct morphologies, sizes, and material properties. Nanocomposites reinforced with small volume fractions of nanospheres can improve composite thermal conductivity, mechanical stiffness and strength, and chemical and thermal resistance without a substantial increase in liquid resin viscosities.25,26 Consequently, nanosphere-reinforced composites typically are easy to process and exhibit relatively uniform nanoreinforcement distributions. Composites reinforced with small amounts of nanoplatelets can also exhibit significantly improved tensile properties, decreased coefficients of thermal expansion, and reduced gas permeability, in comparison with the neat resin.15,25,26 Nanoclay platelets often display a thin/thick flake-like morphology that appears in intercalated (stacked deck of cards) or exfoliated (individual card) structures. Either intercalated or exfoliated nanoplatelets can be idealized as circular plates with a nominal diameter (Dp) and thickness (tp). Note that the aspect ratios (Dp/tp) for exfoliated nanoplatelets can be substantially larger than for intercalated nanoplatelets where the intercalated grouping is considered a single unit. In contrast to nanoclay platelets, which can display intercalated and exfoliated architectures of varying thicknesses, α-ZrP nanoplatelets15 are structures with a nominal thickness, tp = 1 nm, whose diameters can vary (i.e., Dp = 100, 1000 nm). Of course, as the nanoplatelet aspect ratio increases, the corresponding viscosity of the liquid resin containing these platelets can increase appreciably.25,26 In the current study, EC-MAC was used to predict effective elastic properties of composites containing idealized solid silica nanospheres,8 hollow glass spheres,9 and α-ZrP nanoplatelets.15

Zhang et al.8 performed tensile and flexural testing of silica nanosphere/epoxy composites to investigate the effect of the mean distance between nanoparticles on bulk composite properties. The nominal diameter and Young’s moduli of the solid silica nanospheres were Ds = 25 nm and Es = 24 GPa, respectively. Significant improvements in composite elastic moduli and toughness were observed when the interparticle distance was smaller than the silica nanoparticle diameter. Figure 1(a) shows a transmission electron microscopy (TEM) image of 14 v% silica nanospheres in an epoxy matrix from Zhang et al.8 Table 1 contains a summary of nanosphere dimensions and properties, as well as matrix properties from Zhang et al.8 Figure 1.
(a) TEM image of a solid silica nanosphere/epoxy composite from Zhang et al.8 and (b) SEM image of fractured hollow glass spheres from Huang and Gibson.9
Table 1.
Composite material constituent properties
Reinforcement/Matrix Reinforcement dimensions Young’s modulus (GPa) Poisson’s ratio
Solid silica nanospheres/ Ds = 25 nm [8] Es = 24 [8] 0.17 [8]
Epoxy - Em = 3.27 [8] 0.32 [8]
Hollow glass spheres/ Ds = 42 ± 21 nm [9] Es = 70.2 [9] 0.2 [28]
tw = 0.84 nm [9]
Polyester – Em = 4.89 [9] 0.37 [28]

Numbers within brackets denote references.

Huang and Gibson9 performed tensile testing of composites containing hollow glass spheres (Ds = 42 nm, wall thickness tw = 0.84 nm) in a polyester matrix. Such reinforcements have a thin-walled “egg-shell” type of architecture. Figure 1(b) contains a scanning electron microscopy (SEM) image of individual fractured hollow glass nanospheres from Huang and Gibson.9 The measured tensile moduli decreased with increasing amounts of hollow glass spheres. Table 1 contains a summary of hollow glass sphere dimensions and properties, as well as matrix properties from Huang and Gibson.9

Boo et al.15 investigated the effect of nanoplatelet aspect ratio (Dp/tp) on stiffness properties for α-ZrP/epoxy composites. The α-ZrP nanoplatelets had a nominal thickness, tp = 1 nm, and two distinct diameters, Dp = 100, 1000 nm (Figure 2).15 For a nanoplatelet volume fraction, cp = 0.007, nanocomposites prepared using the higher aspect ratio nanoplatelets (Dp/tp = 1000) displayed a 7% improvement in bulk tensile properties in comparison with composites prepared with an equal volume fraction of the lower aspect ratio nanoplatelets (Dp/tp = 100). Table 1 summarizes the α-ZrP nanoplatelet dimensions, Young’s modulus, and matrix properties used in this current study, where the Young’s modulus of α-ZrP nanoplatelets (Ep) was obtained from Matweb.28 Figure 2.
SEM images of α-ZrP nanoplatelets in α-ZrP/epoxy resin composites displaying aspect ratios: (a) Dp/tp = 100 and (b) Dp/tp = 1000 from Boo et al.15

sec.title: Nanoscale defects and other structures
sec.p:
Nanocomposites may also contain nanoscale or microscale defects and other entities such as voids, carbon clusters, and nanoreinforcement agglomerates (Figure 3). An increase in the primary nanoreinforcement volume fraction and/or aspect ratio can result in a significant increase in the nanophased liquid resin viscosity, resulting in an increase in the composite’s void content. Moreover, the nanoreinforcements may become progressively more difficult to disperse in the liquid resin. The likelihood of nanoparticle agglomerates increases with larger nanoreinforcement volume fraction, use of some mixing techniques, and increasing resin viscosity. Figure 3.
Nanoheterogeneities in VGCNF/vinyl ester composites: (a) void (100×), (b) carbon cluster (17,000×), and (c) nanofiber agglomerate (2000×).

The “effective” nanoreinforcement volume fraction may be defined based upon the fraction of reinforcements that are well dispersed. The remaining nanoreinforcements are present in agglomerates or other clustered structures. Well-dispersed nanoreinforcements can enhance material properties while agglomerates and voids can degrade properties. One key challenge is to accurately determine the nanoreinforcement effective volume fraction, as well as the volume fraction of voids, carbon clusters, and agglomerates in real nanocomposites. The concept of the effective volume fraction of nanoreinforcements is more fully explored in the second part of this study.27 Voids, carbon clusters, large platelet tactoids, nanofiber agglomerates can all be loosely idealized as spheres. Provided their mechanical properties and volume fractions were known, the effect of nanoheterogeneities on bulk composite properties could be determined using the modeling approach developed in this work. Of course, voids have null material properties.

sec.title: Effective property estimates using mean field micromechanical approaches
sec.p: A number of mean field micromechanics approaches have been developed to predict effective heterogeneous material properties, particularly for composites containing low volume fractions of reinforcements in an elastic matrix. These include the Mori–Tanaka method (MTM),29,30 the self-consistent method (SCM),31 and various coated inclusion techniques.32,33 These approaches are based upon the classic Eshelby solution34 for the stress and strain field due to the presence of an ellipsoidal inclusion in an infinite domain subjected to uniform far-field loading. Mean field approaches have been used to investigate the effect of nanoplatelets or solid nanofibers on bulk nanoreinforced matrix properties,35,36 and have been modified to account for the effect of varying degrees of nanofiber waviness developed by Hsiao and Daniel,37 Fisher,36 and Fisher et al.38,39

Yu et al.40 developed modified MTM and SCM models for predicting effective elastic properties for nanocomposites containing hollow wavy nanofibers surrounded by an arbitrary number of coating layers. Now, these micromechanical models are extended to estimate effective properties of composites containing multiple nanoheterogeneities with arbitrary shapes and orientations using an approach developed by Nemat-Nasser.33 The EC-MAC was developed herein using MATLAB41 for predicting effective properties for composites containing multiple heterogeneities, each with an arbitrary number of coating layers based upon modified versions of the MTM and SCM. The code allows for either hollow or solid reinforcements. A discussion of some of the basic features, capabilities, and computational procedures associated with EC-MAC is contained in Yu et al.40

sec.title: Modified Mori-Tanaka method for composites containing multiple heterogeneities
sec.p: The MTM assumes that a single ellipsoidal heterogeneity is embedded within a homogeneous matrix domain, whose strain field has been perturbed by other heterogeneities in the system. The MTM uses the continuum-averaged stress and strain fields to predict effective material properties for composites containing arbitrary ellipsoidal heterogeneities.29,30,32,33,42 For a composite with matrix phase (0) and heterogeneity phase (1), the effective fourth-order elastic stiffness tensor, ¯L, can be expressed33 as (1)¯L=L(0):{I+c1(S(1)-I):(A(1)-S(1))-1} :{I+c1S(1):(A(1)-S(1))-1}-1 where (2)A(1)=(L(0)-L(1))-1:L(0)

A(1) is the local strain concentration tensor for the heterogeneity. L(0) and L(1) are the 4th rank elastic stiffness tensors for the matrix and heterogeneity, c1 is the heterogeneity volume fraction, S(1) is the 4th rank Eshelby tensor for the heterogeneity, and I is the 4th rank identity tensor. Here a colon “:” is used to denote the tensor double dot product. The Eshelby tensor (S (1)) accounts for the influence of the aspect ratio/geometry of the heterogeneity on the local strain field. Eshelby tensors for specific reinforcement shapes (spheres, platelets, fibers, etc.) are readily available in the literature.32,33,42 The 4th rank effective compliance tensor, M¯, may be determined by inverting the effective stiffness tensor (equation (1)). After performing requisite orientation averaging to account for the effect of two- and three-dimensional randomly oriented heterogeneities on the calculated effective properties,32,33,42 the effective compliance tensor may be expressed as a 6 × 6 matrix using Voigt notation. For a composite containing parallel nanoplatelets, the effective composite moduli in the longitudinal (EL) and transverse (ET) directions may be expressed as (3)EL=1M¯11=1M¯22 and (4)ET=1M¯33, respectively. Here, M¯11, M¯22, and M¯33 are components of the effective compliance tensor. Similar expressions may be used to define effective elastic moduli for composites containing aligned or two- and three-dimensional randomly oriented heterogeneities of arbitrary shape (fibers, ellipsoids, etc.).

This approach may be extended to the case for composites containing multiple distinct heterogeneities. Suppose that the matrix contains m distinct types of ellipsoidal heterogeneities (k = 1, 2, …, m) each consisting of nk layers (αk = 1, 2, …, nk; k = 1, 2, …, m). As an example, Figure 4 shows a composite containing five (m = 5) distinct types of heterogeneities (k = 1, 2, …, 5) each with a single coating layer (nk = 2, defines the total number of layers for the kth heterogeneity, i.e., particle plus one coating layer). Each type of heterogeneity has distinct elastic properties, shape, and orientation distribution. Based upon a composite containing m distinct types of heterogeneities (k = 1, 2, …, m) each having an arbitrary number of layers (nk) in a matrix (0), the overall elasticity tensor, ¯L, may be expressed33 as (5)¯L=L(0):{I+∑k=1m[∑αk=1nkcαk(S(k)-I):(A(k)(αk)-S(k))-1]} :{I+∑k=1m[∑αk=1nkcαkS(k):(A(k)(αk)-S(k))-1]}-1 where (6)A(k)(αk)=(L(0)-L(k)(αk))-1:L(0) Figure 4.
Schematic of a composite containing five (m = 5) distinct types of heterogeneities (k = 1, 2, …, 5) each with a single coating layer (nk = 2).

A(k)(αk) is the local strain concentration tensor for the αkth layer of the kth heterogeneity (αk = 1, 2, …, nk, k = 1, 2, …, m). Here L(k)(αk) is the 4th rank elastic stiffness tensor for the αkth layer of the kth heterogeneity, cαkis the volume fraction of the αkth layer of the kth heterogeneity, and S(k) is the 4th rank Eshelby tensor common to the heterogeneity and all layers of the kth heterogeneity. Once the overall elasticity tensor, ¯L, is determined for composites containing aligned or randomly oriented heterogeneities, the relevant elastic moduli may be determined using relationships similar to equations (3) and (4).

sec.title: Modified self-consistent method for composites containing multiple heterogeneities
sec.p: The SCM31–33,42 assumes that a single ellipsoidal heterogeneity is embedded within a homogeneous matrix with an unknown effective stiffness tensor, ¯L. For a composite with a matrix phase (0) and heterogeneity phase (1), the effective 4th rank elastic stiffness tensor may be determined iteratively33 from (7)¯L=¯L:{I+c1(S(1)-I):(A(1)¯-S(1))-1} :{I+c1S(1):(A(1)¯-S(1))-1}-1 where (8)A(1)¯=(¯L-L(1))-1:¯L

Here, A(1)¯ is the strain concentration tensor for the heterogeneity (1) based upon the effective composite properties. The effective stiffness tensor (equation (7)) may be determined in an iterative fashion. The 4th rank effective compliance tensor, M¯, may be determined by inverting the effective stiffness tensor (equation (7)), and the effective elastic moduli of composites containing parallel nanoplatelets for the longitudinal (EL) and transverse (ET) directions may be determined in a fashion similar to that for the MTM.

The SCM may also be extended to the case for composites containing multiple distinct heterogeneities. Suppose that the effective homogeneous medium with elastic stiffness tensor, ¯L, contains m distinct types of ellipsoidal heterogeneities (k = 1, 2, …, m) each consisting of nk layers (αk = 1, 2, …, nk) in a matrix (0). Then the overall elasticity tensor, ¯L, may be determined33 from (9)¯L=¯L:{I+∑k=1m[∑αk=1nkcαk(S(k)-I):(A(k)(αk)-S(k))-1]} :{I+∑k=1m[∑αk=1nkcαkS(k):(A(k)(αk)-S(k))-1]}-1 where (10)A(k)(αk)=(¯L-L(k)(αk))-1:¯L
A(k)(αk) is the global strain concentration tensor for the αkth layer of the kth heterogeneity (αk = 1, 2, …, nk, k = 1, 2, …, m).

For arbitrary distributions of reinforcements, the symmetric 4th rank stiffness tensors calculated using equations (1), (5), (7), and (9) will be generally anisotropic. For the case of aligned, two-dimensional randomly oriented, and three-dimensional randomly oriented heterogeneities the calculated elasticity tensor will display orthotropic, transversely isotropic, and isotropic material symmetries, respectively. Hence, determination of longitudinal, in-plane, and transverse moduli for these three cases is of particular interest.

sec.title: Effective elastic moduli for nanocomposites containing multiple nanoheterogeneities
sec.p: In this study, EC-MAC was used to determine the effective elastic moduli of composites containing a combination of nanoreinforcements (solid silica8 and hollow glass9 nanospheres, and α-ZrP nanoplatelets15) and voids, assuming that all heterogeneities were well dispersed in the matrix and perfectly bonded to the other phases. In all calculations, the composites' effective moduli, Eeff, were normalized by their respective matrix modulus, Em, in order to clearly illustrate the effect of the nanoheterogeneities. Table 1 contains a summary of the composite reinforcement and matrix properties used in this study.

sec.title: Effective elastic moduli of composites containing nanospheres
sec.p:
EC-MAC was used to estimate the elastic moduli of composites comprised of solid silica nanospheres in an epoxy matrix. Table 1 contains a summary of the relevant nanosphere and matrix mechanical properties used in the calculations. Figure 5 shows a plot comparing the predicted normalized effective elastic moduli (Eeff /Em), obtained using both the MTM and SCM modules within EC-MAC, as a function of the volume fraction of solid silica nanospheres. The predicted effective composite moduli increased with an increasing volume fraction of nanospheres. Note that the SCM led to slightly lower estimates of Eeff compared to those obtained using the MTM. Experimentally measured tensile moduli from Zhang et al.8 are included in the figure. While there was a fair degree of scatter in the measured moduli, the two micromechanical solutions reasonably matched the mean experimental response over the range of volume fractions. Figure 5.
Measured8 and predicted effective elastic moduli for solid silica nanosphere/epoxy composites.

Similar effective property estimates were obtained for composites comprised of hollow glass nanospheres in a polyester matrix. Huang and Gibson9 measured the tensile properties for such composites. The hollow nanospheres were essentially thin shell-like reinforcements, i.e., Ri/Ro ≈ 0.98 where Ri and Ro are the inner and outer sphere radii, respectively (Figure 1(b)). Hence, the majority of the volume of each sphere corresponded to void space. The glass spheres were simulated in EC-MAC using a two-layer idealization, where the inner layer was ascribed essentially null material properties and the outer layer was comprised of glass. Table 1 contains a summary of material properties used in the analysis. Figure 6 contains a plot of the measured9 and predicted effective composite modulus as a function of the reinforcement volume fraction, where the MTM and SCM modules of EC-MAC were used. Again, the SCM led to slightly lower effective property estimates in comparison to those obtained using the MTM. In contrast to the case involving solid silica nanospheres, the effective modulus decreased with increasing volume fraction of hollow glass spheres. This makes sense given the relatively low fraction of solid glass contained in each sphere. The predicted moduli correlated reasonably well with the experimental data from Huang and Gibson.9 The predicted effective moduli for a polyester matrix containing spherical voids only (i.e., no glass outer wall) fell significantly below the measured and predicted values for the hollow glass sphere/polyester composites (Figure 6). This suggests that the very thin glass outer wall significantly contributes to the overall composite properties. This approach with voids and hollow spheres could be extended to predicting properties of low density closed-cell foams. Figure 6.
Measured9 and predicted effective elastic moduli for hollow glass sphere/polyester composites and a polyester matrix containing spherical voids.

sec.title: Effective elastic moduli of α-Zrp nanoplatelet/epoxy nanocomposites containing voids
sec.p:
The MTM module in EC-MAC was used to predict the effective moduli of α-ZrP nanoplatelet/epoxy nanocomposites containing randomly oriented nanoplatelets. Two different nanoplatelet aspect ratios were considered (Dp/tp = 100, 1000). Table 1 contains a summary of nanoplatelet and matrix properties used in the analyses. Figure 7(a) contains a plot of the effective composite moduli as a function of the heterogeneity volume fraction. As expected, the bulk composite stiffness increased as the amount of nanoplatelets was increased. In addition, the moduli for composites containing higher aspect ratio nanoplatelets (Dp/tp = 1000) was 13% greater (at 0.7 v% of nanoplatelets) than those for composites with lower aspect ratio reinforcements (Dp/tp = 100). Experimental data from Boo et al.15 are included in the figure. The predicted solutions fell within the error band of the measured values, while in both cases they slightly over-estimated the mean experimental response. Figure 7.
Measured15 and predicted effective elastic moduli for α-ZrP nanoplatelet/epoxy composites containing a) nanoplatelets (Dp/tp = 100, 1000) calculated using both the MTM and SCM, and b) nanoplatelets (Dp/tp = 100, 1000) and voids (cp = cv) calculated using the MTM.

Even small amounts of high aspect ratio nanoreinforcements can result in a substantial increase in liquid resin viscosity, which can lead to difficulties in degassing and increased composite void content. The disparity between the predicted and measured moduli is likely due to some combination of void content, poorly dispersed nanoplatelets, or nanoplatelet agglomerates. In order to assess the effect of spherical voids on the bulk elastic properties, additional calculations were performed using the MTM for composites containing both nanoplatelets and voids. In these simulations, it was assumed that the volume fraction of voids was the same as for nanoplatelets (cv = cp). The predicted effective moduli for composites containing both nanoplatelets and voids appear in Figure 7(b) as the dashed lines. The presence of voids resulted in roughly a 3% decrease in the effective composite moduli, which better matched the mean experimental values from Boo et al.15 If the effective nanoplatelet volume fraction and actual void content were known, similar calculations could be performed that better account for the effect of nanoplatelet dispersion and defects on bulk nanocomposite properties. As an aside, for randomly oriented voids the predicted moduli will be insensitive to the void aspect ratio. EC-MAC may also be used, however, to assess the effect of preferentially aligned elongated voids on effective material properties. Similarly, the effect of uncertainties in constituent properties on bulk composite moduli could readily be assessed using EC-MAC.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The EC-MAC was developed for predicting effective properties for composites containing multiple distinct nanoheterogeneities (spheres, platelets, voids, straight and/or wavy fibers, etc.), each with an arbitrary number of coating layers based upon either the modified MTM and self-consistent method. The influence of nanoreinforcement elastic properties and solid/hollow geometries on the effective elastic moduli was addressed. The predicted effective elastic moduli obtained using EC-MAC matched well with results from the literature for solid silica nanosphere/epoxy, hollow glass nanosphere/polyester, and α-ZrP nanoplatelet/epoxy composites. The notion of “effective volume fraction” was introduced to denote the fraction of nanoreinforcements that contribute to overall composite properties through their good dispersion; such a concept may prove useful in analyzing composites containing significant amounts of agglomerated or otherwise clustered constituents.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research was supported by the U.S. Department of Energy under grant DE-FC26-06NT42755 (Technology area development manager, William Joost).

ack.title: Acknowledments
ack.p: The authors are especially grateful to Professors Sia Nemat-Nasser and Frank Fisher for their enlightening conversations on micromechanical model development.

sec.title: Conflicts of interest
sec.p: None declared.
